intro: Malveopsis vitifolia, commonly known as the grapeleaf mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its large, heart-shaped leaves that resemble grape leaves, hence its common name. The plant produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in summer, adding ornamental value to gardens. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it suitable for arid and semi-arid climates. Botanically, it belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes other plants like hibiscus and cotton.
